div1.p: Carter explains the connection between his father and Walter Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, February 10, 1948
div1.opener:
HENRY R. CARTER, JR., M. D.
WOODWARD BUILDING
BIRMINGHAM 3, ALA.
February 10, 1948
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
102-110 Second Avenue
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter of February 7th recieved. The subject you have taken is certainly
an interesting one. Relative to the connection of Dr. Carter and Major Reed,
it was due to a diagnostic board, Finley, Gorgas and Carter, who selected the
yellow fever patients used by Reed in his experiments

Mr. Reed has sent you data of father's papers, which I hope were what you
wonted. If you desire more we can send you more of his papers, but they are
in nearly all the medical journals.

Dr. T. H. Griffitts a retired officer of the U.S.P.H.S. published a short
biography of Dr. Carter in the Southern Medical Journal Vol 32, Aug. 1939,
pages 841-848 which is complete.

In the Rochefellow Foundation's annual report 1925, page 211 is a short
biography, but it shows how much Dr. Carter did for them relative to yellow
fever.

During the last years of Dr. Carter's life, while he was confined to his bed
because of apoplexy he wrote “Early History of Yellow Fever”, which caused
the Rochefellow Foundation to accept yellow fever to be a disease which
occurred in Africa, to it is due all the sanitation they have given that part of
the world, and was a blessing to the troops that landed in Africa during the
last world war.

The two little biographies will give you data that will show you what Dr. Carter
did with yellow fever and the fact that in 1904 Sir Ronald Ross proposed his
name for the Noble Prize, shows he was accepted as one of those who advanced
Medicine.

Hoping that the data we are sending is what you wish, but if additional is re-
quired let us know and we will be glad to send it. I know you were glad to see
Dr. Finley's papers as they are seldom found.
We are looking forward to the arrival of the reprint which you mentioned.
